texts.shortText: Small, rather flat, dirty-white barnacle with six shell valves and a membranous base. Aperture large and closed by 4 neatly-interlocking plates. Projecting finger-like ridges on the shell plates produce a characteristic star-shaped outline, which is the best character for identification.

Global: From Kenya to Angola.

Local/Regional: Throughout region, but more common to the east.

Common intertidal barnacle all along the east and south coast, rare on west coast, where largely replaced by the similar looking but introduced Balanus glandula. Recruitment occurs mainly in spring and autumn and mean longevity is only about 1.5 years.
Like all barnacles – feeds on small living and non-living organic particles filtered from the water column.

Almost all barnacles are hermaphroditic, but cross-fertilisation is the rule and the penis of one individual is extended out of the body and into an adjacent individual to transfer sperm. As each animal is permanently attached to the rock the number of potential mates is limited by the length of the penis, which can be up to 3-times the diameter of the shell (relatively the longest of any animal group). The eggs are initially brooded in the mantle cavity and larvae later released. These swim and feed in the water column and go though several stages until ready to settle. Larvae are chemically attracted to older individuals, encouraging the formation of closely–packed colonies.
Easily confused with the Pacific barnacle Balanus glandula, which occurs in similar intertidal habitats. However, that species has a calcareous base and is mostly restricted to the west coast.

Biccard, A (2012). Taxonomy, systematics and biogeography of South African Cirripedia (Thoracica). Master's thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M, & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 82)

Dye, AH (1993). Aspects of the population dynamics of Chthamalus dentatus (Crustacea: Cirripedia) on the Transkei coast of southern Africa. South African Journal of Marine Science, 13(1), 25–32.
